title: 9.1 Minimum and Maximum
content:
Section 9.1

Minimum and Maximum

Summary

Find min or max in n-1 comparisons; find both in 3⌊n/2⌋ comparisons.

Key Points

  • Finding min: n-1 comparisons (compare each to current min)
  • Finding max: also n-1 comparisons
  • Finding both naively: 2(n-1) comparisons
  • Better: compare pairs first, then min with mins, max with maxes
  • This gives 3⌊n/2⌋ comparisons total

Example

Array of 8 elements: 4 pairwise comparisons, 3 to find min of losers, 3 to find max of winners = 10 total (vs 14 naive).

Why It Matters

Shows careful algorithm design can reduce constant factors.
